segments.text: Well, as I was saying, Mr. Burnett, the whole community really was ready to pull together, and they did pull together.
They supported the school and supported us tremendously well.
And I might add, I think our coaching didn't hurt anything, because for the first time in, I guess, Anderson's history, we had a winning basketball team and a winning softball team.
We had a good track team, but our star track man was blind in one eye.
And when they put him in a lane, he would veer across all the other lanes and invariably become disqualified.
He could run faster than everybody, even though he ran twice as far, but he never won anything much.
So I enjoyed myself in Anderson.
I made many good friends there.
I did a great deal of hunting and fishing in the community and took part in community life and community church work.
And my wife and I really, truly enjoyed our four years at Anderson.
I came to Texas A&M University on November the 1st, 1939.
I had not particularly cared about leaving Anderson unless I could go to a college or university somewhere because I was quite happy in Anderson.
But a series, a chain of circumstances made it such that during the summer I came over to A&M
and visited with Dr. George Summey, who was then head of the English Department at Texas A&M.

Dr. Summey was a close friend of Dr. LL Click, who was my major professor at Austin while I was working during the summers of 35, 6, 7, and 8 on my master's degree, which I did, in fact, receive in English from the University of Texas in Austin in the summer of 1938.
Dr. Click had told me, if you ever happen to be in College Station, go by and visit Dr. Summey.
He's a fine man.
He and his wife are wonderful people.
They are Virginians.
So I was interested and did, in fact, just drop by to visit Dr. Summey with my wife.
And while I was there, he encouraged me to put an application with him.
He said he had no openings at the time, but that if one turned up, he thought he would love to have me, that Dr. Click had written a very nice letter to him about me, and he was glad I'd come by.
So this was all rather informal and incidental, and I didn't think much of it.

But after I had started work in Anderson and had worked for a month, along about October the 27th or 28th, I got a phone call from Dr. Summey saying that one of his young instructors had terminated his contract and that he needed an immediate replacement and could I come as an acting instructor in English at Texas A&M University.
To me, this seemed like a great opportunity.
And indeed, after the years have gone by, I will say I still think it was a great opportunity.
And I am glad that I accepted the job.
I had a hard time talking the school board in Anderson into letting us both go because my wife, by this time, was teaching in the grades in Anderson.
And they were rather hard put to it to find a replacement.
But they did feel, I think, that having a teacher there in Anderson who was hired by a major university from this small school was a tribute to the school.
And so after some discussion, they agreed to let me terminate my contract with them and let me come on over to Texas A&M University.
This I did on November the 1st, 1939, and joined the Department of English.
In those days, A&M was, I must say, not at all the sort of school it is now.
The campus was...
I won't say it was a sea of mud, but there were very few sidewalks.
The winters were very wet and quite often cold.
And one got the impression much of the time that he was just simply slopping through mud from place to place, no matter where he went on the campus.
Many of the buildings were rather old and antiquated as far as heating and so on were concerned.
There was no such thing as air conditioning and all the comforts that people now know.
And life wasn't primitive.
I mean, we weren't living in tents or shacks.
There were some shacks that we taught in.
But nevertheless, it was a rather small campus.
I just remember the exact enrollment at the time.
I would say in the neighborhood of 6,000, something of this sort.
And naturally, all core members, that is, all students were members of the core ROTC, with the exception of a very few people who were handicapped and could not participate.
However, it was an all male, all core, highly traditional, small land grant college that I joined as a member of the English staff.
I could talk for a long time about some of the sort of interesting things that went on.
There was the old Cave of the Winds, which had something like eight or ten of the young people, young men in the department, instructors and assistant professors, had their desks in the same room.

And when each one had a student sitting in front of him, was trying to go over a paper with the student, and two were talking, and one was playing some sort of a recorder, and one was hammering on the edge of his desk, something of this sort, it really sounded like the Tower of Babel.
And how anybody got anything done under conditions like this, I don't know.
Still, we did manage to do the job.
I think did a very good job, really.
English department at that time had no graduate programs at all.
We were primarily a service department.
That is to say, we taught the basic English courses, freshman composition, logic, which I'm sorry to say has rather disappeared from the curriculum now.
It was a good course.
Both I and my colleagues and our students, I think, enjoyed course in pure logic.
literature courses of various types, both American and English literature, and an undergraduate degree program.
But we had no graduate operation.
All of the teachers were full-time teachers, and most of them were experienced teachers.
And I do think that this was probably a good thing, because it brought the students there all under the tutelage of experienced people who were
heavily loaded who were, however, dedicated to teaching.
They were not concerned with research of any sort because there was no time for it and really no purpose in it.
And it was a teaching institution so far as the English department was concerned at that time, though of course it has changed greatly in the years that have gone by.
Some of the interesting places that were, that I remember were cases
the little coffee shop down under the YMCA building.
And many of the old Aggies I know will remember cases where students and faculty alike gathered for coffee and talk and so on, in a sort of a dim, Ross Geller on a small scale atmosphere.
And the old Aggieland Inn, opposite, straight across the street from where Sabisa Hall now stands, approximately in front of the hospital.
Now this was a beautiful building.
And it was also a hotel, and the only one on the campus.
It had rooms for visitors, not very many rooms.
It had a lovely downstairs coffee shop, and virtually all the faculty members would go there at some time in the morning to sit around a big horseshoe-shaped bar and talk to their neighbors.
The core life was very interesting.
rigorous for the students.
I often thank God I had not been an Aggie student when I would walk by some of the dorms and literally hear the splat, splat, splat of the board going on in the corridors.
Hazing was forbidden by regulation, but it was carried on both considerably and regularly at that time.
And the upperclassmen
had many, many traditions and rules and regulations and restrictions designed to harden and mold the younger freshmen.
I have never really decided what my opinion of the core life is.
I certainly can see that in many ways it's valuable on the basis that if a young man could survive the rigors of core life and did survive these rigors,
Then he felt a sense of courage and perhaps the ability to survive anywhere.
And I have heard old Aggies say just that.

That is, that simply knowing that they had survived four years of corps life in A&M and come out perhaps a corps leader or a staff officer in the corps had given them the feeling that they could make it anywhere they went under any conditions.
On the other hand, I have seen.

a number of students, good students, literally ruined by the core life, emotionally and physically and intellectually seriously hurt because they were not geared for this sort of thing and yet were forced into a mold and a pattern which they weren't fitted for.
And some of them, I have a feeling, never really recovered from the scars of going through what to them was years of absolute torture and degradation in the core.
So, like any other human institution, I guess we could say that the old corps at least had values and it had serious defects.
The corps life has changed a great deal now and I know very little about it.
It is a relatively small portion of present day A&M life because it represents, oh, I don't know, not more than 11 or 12 percent of the total student body at this time.

As I stayed through the 1940s, I might digress a little to say that I went for a summer or two to the University of Wisconsin proposing to work on a PhD degree in English at the University of Wisconsin.
And I had some very fine teachers there and was enjoying my work.
But World War II interrupted this, and I never went back to work on a PhD degree.
I never received one.
In 1941, on July the 3rd, a very happy and interesting experience occurred to me.
My only child and only son was born.
Well, he is now Dr. Justin E. Kidd.
And much against his father's wishes, he majored in English at the University of Virginia, received his PhD in 1973 in English at that
fine old institution up in our home part of the country.
And he is now an assistant professor of English on the staff of Louisiana State University in Shreveport.
I might go a little further to say that he has two lovely daughters.
My granddaughter is Julie, now age nine, and Helen, now age eight.
And recently, my first grandson and his first son, Mr.
James Edward Kidd, who, as I speak, is 12 days old, and a very fine baby as babies go, if I do say so.
Well, Justin was born, and I was coming along in the Department of English.
I had advanced by 19 and 41 to the rank of instructor, was no longer an acting instructor.
And I had found an interest in radio writing,
radio production.
Texas A&M then owned its own radio station and I worked on a contract basis in producing, writing and producing a number of radio series.
Some of these were under contract to the Texas Education Agency.
I remember one series we did was called Jobs Ahead.
We did this series of 13 shows per
semester, I believe there were 26 shows a year once a week for the long session.
And we wrote the scripts for this.
These were career orientation shows aimed at the high schools and junior high schools of the state of Texas.
And we dramatized various kinds of careers.
And then we had a little group of students and student wives and faculty wives and interested students, just people who were interested in radio.
And they made up our cast, and they were very good.
Many of them have gone into commercial radio and TV work and have done well.
This was an all-volunteer cast, and I was the director, and we did it all in the old station and had some very fine times.
Another series that we did was called Texas Turns to Science, which dramatized recent scientific discoveries and researches carried on through the research arm of Texas A&M University.
Still another series, which was very successful, was called Man to Man.
It was a series of 13 shows, I believe, if I remember correctly, based on industrial case histories in the field of human engineering or human relations.
The basis for this was some studies that had been carried on by the Texas Engineering Extension Service.
They had a number of case histories, problems that had come up in actual industries and businesses.
We dramatized these and set them in dramatic form and presented them.
Now, all these shows were presented live over the air.
We had something like 40 or 45 stations carrying these shows on good time and got very good reception from all the series.
We were real proud of our series.
This man-to-man show was extremely successful.
As I recall, it was picked up by a number of the major airlines
and some of the manufacturing companies and others who bought the tapes to play to their employees and their supervisors, foremen and what have you.
And we thought this was a good show.

I also had got interested in creative writing and was doing a little creative writing on the side and was lucky enough to sell a number of short stories to such commercial magazines as Field and Stream, Argosy Magazine, Rod and Gun in Canada, Giant Western,
other magazines of this sort.

And I was also writing some more literary-type short stories, things which were non-commercial but which were stories of some literary merit, I guess, because three of the short stories I wrote received mention as distinctive American short stories of the year in the several years of the Foley anthologies.
And some, one of them at least, was picked up for anthologizing in a
anthology of short stories edited by the late Dr. William Perry of the University of Texas.
And in this anthology, my story, which was called Low Road Go Down, was in company with some of the great Texas writers, Dobie and Gibson and others, Katherine Ann Porter and so on.
And I really felt that this was a major tribute.
This same story was anthologized in a textbook, which was used as a
text in a survey of literature in a number of colleges and institutions.
And so I did get some literary recognition from these stories, but after a while the main played out and I seemed to lose the touch somehow or other and didn't do much more fiction writing.
I did, however, do a great deal of contract writing for various agencies

here located on the campus of Texas Forest Service, Texas Engineering Experiment Station, and other agencies, and I found I had all the summer work that I could possibly handle offered me long before the summers came just to write for various agencies.
World War I was a very sad and agonizing time, and many of my good friends and fine A&M students died, and I was saddened with the news of each death

My wife's only brother, my only brother-in-law, Robert Canterbury, who was also a student at A&M in his sophomore year when war broke out, went off with his friends to service, and he was killed overseas.

And the names of all my friends and my students who died are on the plaque over at the MSC, and I never passed this without reliving some of the misery and horror of this time, which people of this vantage shared.
I, myself,
thought that I would go into the Navy.

But before my commission, which was on the way from Washington, could come through, I was frozen here at A&M and spent the war years right here teaching mathematics and elementary cryptography to ASTP trainees, Navy trainees, and so on.
After the war, I continued to teach and do contract writing.
In 1968, I became assistant to the dean of the graduate college.
and in 1972 became assistant dean of the Graduate College.
My present job is assistant dean of the Graduate College.
I teach two sections of speech 403 in the long semesters and do not teach it all in the summertime, but devote my time to the work of the Graduate College.
I will say that my work in the Graduate College, which takes up about really most of my time, is work which I enjoy perhaps more than anything I've ever done.
It is work of a general administrative nature.
And I work very closely with Dean George Kunze.
And I'm very proud of our graduate college, of its growth and development since it became autonomous in 1968 when Dean Kunze took over as dean, and Dean Leo Berner, and now associate dean.
And I joined him as the three executive deans of the graduate college.
We have a grand staff.
It's the finest group of people anyone could possibly hope to work with.
They're dedicated to the work.
They know what they're doing.
Time means nothing to them in terms of getting the job done.

And I think that the success and growth of the Graduate College, and I want to put this on record, is due primarily to Dean Kunze's terrific personal leadership qualities and his organizational ability.
When he became dean, the work of the Graduate College was a rather scattered and chaotic sort of thing.
Graduate enrollment was in the neighborhood of 2,000 or 2,100, perhaps not quite that many.
But the whole program was diversified and scattered and not well organized at all, in my opinion.
He brought organization and order into the whole thing, and he,

Dr. Charles Pennell and Mr. Lester Wood developed the only computerized graduate student record keeping system in the nation, which now carries all of the records of the graduate college and the individual students from the moment of admission to the moment of graduation on the computer.
Any student and any advisor, any member of the graduate faculty can find out instantly exactly where his student is, what he's doing,
part of the program he is in, when he may be expected to graduate, what his deficiencies are, what his financial supports are, and so on.
This system has attracted nationwide interest.
Dean Kunze has several times been asked to present it before the Council of Graduate Schools in the United States.
And graduate deans from all over the country have come here
to look at it and to envy it, to be frank about it.

I don't think that there's another institution of higher learning in this country which has perfected its computerization of its graduate student record keeping to the degree that A&M has under Dean Kunze's leadership and supervision.
And Dean Kunze has been recognized by the national graduate community for his work here.
He has served on a number of accreditation teams for the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools.
He's been chairman of these teams, just recently has returned from a visit of an accreditation team to an institution in Georgia, of which he was the chairman of the team.
He has recently been the only graduate dean in the nation appointed to a blue ribbon federal commission charged with looking into
the issue of affirmative action in employment among institutions of higher education in this country.
And his associates on this commission are such men as the president of Harvard, president of Princeton, the president of Michigan State, and other outstanding educational leaders, both men and women.
This is a very important committee, and it's a tribute to Dean Kunze that he's been chosen to do this work.
He's a grand person to work with.
And believe me, I feel that A&M is very, very lucky to have him.
I might add he is an ex-Agin, a survivor of the old Corps.
And perhaps he would not share my total opinions of the Corps.
Nevertheless, he's a great product of A&M.
He has his PhD from Penn State University.
Now, Mr. Burnett, this sort of brings me up to date.
If you have any questions you'd like to ask me in the remaining time, go ahead.
Mr. Kidd, a big change that you saw come to Texas A&M was coeducation.
What are your thoughts on that?
Well, my thoughts, of course, Mr. Burnett, are that I approve very highly of the coming of coeducation to Texas A&M University.
When I came here, A&M was, of course, an all-male institution, and I taught under these circumstances for a quarter of a century.
And I thought it was a great school.
I was fond of the boys and so on.
But I felt also all this time that coeducation,
would in time be inevitable if A&M were to achieve a true status of major university.
I know there was a great deal of opposition at all levels, both from the students, from old Aggies, and from some people who were not Aggies.
And strangely enough, from many women who felt that this would be a very bad thing for girls to come to A&M.
But the change was made over a period of time.
And with some struggle and distress,
And now I think everybody has accepted it very, very well indeed.
We have something like 7,000 girls and a fair portion of these in the graduate school.
I teach girls.
There are girls in the class with you.
And I will say this, that these girls perform at a very high level.
They are good students.
They're capable.
And they are career-oriented in that sense.
I mean, they probably will marry and so on, but they intend to use what they learn at college.
and to make a career and also to marry and have children.
And I think they're very high quality people.
They're very good people.
And I think it's been very good for the school to have them.
And it has brought an atmosphere of wholeness and what I would think of as a university type atmosphere to A&M.
And of course, I think it is certainly a major factor in the recent astounding growth of the institution.
and the development of the institution is the coming of the girls and women to A&M, and I'm all for it.
Mr. Kidd, just in the three years that I've been here, I've seen A&M grow just extremely fast.
All the buildings popping up and the number of students is increasing.
What are your thoughts on this?
How big do you think A&M can get?
Do you think anything is suffering because of its size, or is it improving?
Well, so far I think the programs are good programs, and they're working.
And the proof of the fact that they're working is that
A&M graduates not only are placed well, that is, they do get jobs and get jobs perhaps more easily thanks to a fine placement service than the graduates of many other schools.
But the important thing is that they do well in these jobs.
The history of A&M graduates everywhere is a history of success by and large.
They contribute well.
They're good citizens.
They live well.
And I think this is fine.
Now, I do think that there probably is an upper limit to the growth that we can tolerate because both of space and facilities.
And I don't think that we have the space, literally, for the necessary labs and the classrooms and so on.
And of course, there is a point of no return.
I don't know just where that point is, but I do know that
The administration and the Board of Regents are probably taking a very hard look at the 30,000 figure as a potential maximum for at least the coming few years.
And strangely enough, I have a feeling we may well reach that 30,000 figure within the next two or three years.
So I don't know where we go from there.
There are buildings and so forth on the drawing boards, but it takes some years for them to be constructed.
And I just really don't know what the upshot will be.
I think right now we're in a good position as far as growth is concerned.
Well, Mr. Kidd, I've been extremely interested in your talk.
I really appreciate your help here in this project.
I'm glad to get it on tape, and it's going to be some interesting information.
All right.
Well, thank you, Mr. Burnett, and I was glad to help you.
